sen.j: 令制国一覧 > 東山道 > 近江国
sen.e: the catalog of 'ryoseikoku (province)' >Tosando>Omi Province
the catalog of 'ryoseikoku' (province) > Tosando> Omi Province
sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置を移動、スペース追加
sen.e: the catalog of 'ryoseikoku' (province) > Tosando> Omi Province

sen.j: 近江国 （おうみのくに） は、かつて日本の地方行政区分だった令制国の一つで、東山道に位置する。
sen.e: Omi Province was one of the provinces, the former local administration division, and is located in Tosando.
Omi Province was one of the provinces, the former local administration division, and is located in Tosando.
Omi Province was one of the provinces, the former local administration division, and is located in Tosando.

sen.j: 現在の滋賀県を範囲とする。
sen.e: Omi Province sometimes means present Shiga prefecture.
Omi Province sometimes means present Shiga Prefecture.
Omi Province sometimes means present Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 江州（ごうしゅう）と呼ぶこともある。
sen.e: It is sometimes called Goshu.
It is sometimes called Goshu.
It is sometimes called Goshu.

sen.j: 延喜式での格は大国、近国。
sen.e: According to "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), Omi Province was categorized as 国司国等級区分, Kingoku (provinces close to Kyoto).
sen.cmt: 国司国等級区分の定訳が見つかりませんでした。
sen.e: According to the Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), Omi Province was categorized as Taikoku (major provinces), Kingoku (provinces close to Kyoto).
sen.cmt: *「国司国等級区分」→ウェブで確認したところ、「大国」と記載されているため、こちらに基づき、原文・訳文を修正しました。(用語集参照)クォーテーション削除
sen.e: According to the Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), Omi Province was categorized as Taikoku (major provinces), Kingoku (provinces close to Kyoto).

sen.j: 古事記には「近つ淡海国」「淡海国」「近淡海国」とも記載された。
sen.e: "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) described it as 'Chikatsu Awaumi-no-kuni' and/or 'Awami-no-kuni.'
sen.cmt: 「近つ淡海国」「淡海国」「近淡海国」の漢字表記の差異を表現出来ませんでした。最初と最後は同音と思われ、ローマ字で記しています。
sen.e: The Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) described it as 'Chikatsu Awaumi no kuni' and/or 'Awami no kuni.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーション・ハイフン削除、The Kojikiとしました。
sen.e: The Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) described it as 'Chikatsu Awaumi no kuni' and/or 'Awami no kuni.'

tit.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 近江国は、当初は淡海（あはうみ、あふみ）と書き、近淡海（ちかつあはうみ）とも呼んだ。
sen.e: In early days, Omi Province was described as 'Awaumi', 'Afumi' or 'Chikatsu Awaumi-no-kuni.'
sen.cmt: 漢字表記の差異を表現できていません。
sen.e: In early days, Omi Province was described as 'Awaumi,' 'Afumi' or 'Chikatsu Awaumi no kuni.'
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を移動、Awaumi-no-kuniのハイフン消去
sen.e: In early days, Omi Province was described as 'Awaumi,' 'Afumi' or 'Chikatsu Awaumi no kuni.'

sen.j: 当時の琵琶湖の呼称をそのまま国の名にしたものである。
sen.e: The then name of Lake Biwa was used as the name of the division.
The then name of Lake Biwa was used as the name of the division.
The then name of Lake Biwa was used as the name of the division.

sen.j: 国府は栗太郡勢多におかれ、1964年に現在の大津市三大寺で遺跡が発見された。
sen.e: Kokufu (provincial office)' was placed in Seta, Kurita County and the remains of the office was found in the present Sandaiji, Otsu City in 1964.
Kokufu (provincial office) was placed in Seta, Kurita County and the remains of the office were found in the present Sandaiji, Otsu City in 1964.
sen.cmt: was→wereとし、クォーテーション削除
sen.e: Kokufu (provincial office) was placed in Seta, Kurita County and the remains of the office were found in the present Sandaiji, Otsu City in 1964.

sen.j: 国府の遺跡が発見された最初の例である。
sen.e: It was the first case that the remain of a provincial office was found.
It was the first case that the remains of a provincial office were found.
It was the first case that the remains of a provincial office were found.

sen.j: 国分寺・国分尼寺は、はじめ甲可寺（現甲賀市信楽町、紫香楽宮跡とされてきた）。
sen.e: At first, the provincial monastery and nunnery in that area was Koka-dera Temple (Shigaraki-cho Town, Koga City, Shiga Prefecture at present, the remain of 'Shigaraki no miya'),
sen.cmt: )は跡の直後につく、と考えました。
sen.e: At first, the provincial monastery and nunnery in that area was Koka-dera Temple (Shigaraki-cho, Koka City, Shiga Prefecture at present, the remains of 'Shigaraki no miya'),
sen.cmt: Shigaraki-choとし、Koga City→Koka City、the remain→the remainsに修正
sen.e: At first, the provincial monastery and nunnery in that area was Koka-dera Temple (Shigaraki-cho, Koka City, Shiga Prefecture at present, the remains of 'Shigaraki no miya'),

sen.j: その後、瀬田廃寺（大津市神領）にうつり、焼失の後、820年（弘仁11年）に国昌寺跡（大津市国分）に移された。
sen.e: Afterwards, the provincial monastery and nunnery was transferred to Seta Ruin Temple (Jinryo, Otsu City) and then it was transferred to the site of Kokusho-ji Temple in 820 after Seta Ruin Temple was burned down,

Afterwards, the provincial monastery and nunnery was transferred to Seta Ruin Temple (Jinryo, Otsu City) and then it was transferred to the site of Kokusho-ji Temple in 820 after Seta Ruin Temple was burned down,

Afterwards, the provincial monastery and nunnery was transferred to Seta Ruin Temple (Jinryo, Otsu City) and then it was transferred to the site of Kokusho-ji Temple in 820 after Seta Ruin Temple was burned down,

sen.j: ここでは最澄が若き日に修学しているとされる。
sen.e: It is said that Saicho studied there when he was young.
It is said that Saicho studied there when he was young.
It is said that Saicho studied there when he was young.

sen.j: 飛鳥京から藤原宮時代の木簡（大化の改新以後～律令制前）には近江国を「近水海」と記載されている。
sen.e: In 'mokkan (a narrow strip of wood on which an official message is written: made after 'Taika no Kaishin' (Great Reformation of the Taika Era) till the introduction of the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code))' made in the period fromAsuka-kyo place to Fujiwara-kyo palace, Omi Province was described as 'Chikatsu no umi(近水海).'
sen.cmt: 「近水海」の読み方も曖昧ですし、また漢字表記と他の漢字表記の差を表現できませんでした。
sen.e: In a 'mokkan' (a narrow strip of wood on which an official message is written: made after 'Taika no Kaishin' [Great Reformation of the Taika Era] till the introduction of the Ritsuryo system [a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code]) made in the period from Asuka-kyo place to Fujiwara-kyo palace, Omi Province was described as 'Chikatsu no umi' (近水海).
sen.cmt: In a 'mokkan'とし、カッコ表記修正、クォテーションの位置を移動、スペース追加
sen.e: In a 'mokkan' (a narrow strip of wood on which an official message is written: made after 'Taika no Kaishin' [Great Reformation of the Taika Era] till the introduction of the Ritsuryo system [a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code]) made in the period from Asuka-kyo place to Fujiwara-kyo palace, Omi Province was described as 'Chikatsu no umi' (近水海).

sen.j: また「近淡」（海は缺損か）と記載するものもある。
sen.e: Omi Province was sometimes described as 'Chikatsu umi(近淡) ('umi' was dropped?).
Omi Province was sometimes described as 'Chikatsu umi' (近淡) ('umi' was dropped?).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション修正、スペース追加
sen.e: Omi Province was sometimes described as 'Chikatsu umi' (近淡) ('umi' was dropped?).

sen.j: 近江国は畿内に隣接し、合計で3度天皇の住居（宮）が構えられている。
sen.e: Omi Province was adjacent to Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) and the palaces for the emperors were established three times in total.
Omi Province was adjacent to the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) and the palaces for the emperors were established three times in total.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去、the Kinai regionとしました。
sen.e: Omi Province was adjacent to the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) and the palaces for the emperors were established three times in total.

sen.j: 大津宮（京） 天智天皇 - 弘文天皇
sen.e: Otsu no Miya Palace (Kyo) Emperor: Tenchi - Emperor Kobun
sen.cmt: :を入れる方が分かり易いと思い入れました。
sen.e: Otsu no Miya Palace (Kyo): Emperor Tenchi - Emperor Kobun
Otsu no Miya Palace (Kyo): Emperor Tenchi - Emperor Kobun

sen.j: 紫香楽宮 聖武天皇
sen.e: Shigaraki no Miya Palace: Emperor Shomu
sen.cmt: :を入れる方が分かり易いと思い入れました。
sen.e: Shigaraki no Miya Palace: Emperor Shomu
Shigaraki no Miya Palace: Emperor Shomu

sen.j: 伝保良宮（陪都） 淳仁天皇
sen.e: Den Hora no Miya Palace (secondary capital city):Emperor Junnin
sen.cmt: :を入れる方が分かり易いと思い入れました。 保良宮は「ほらのみや」ですが、伝保良宮の読み方が分かりませんでした。
sen.e: Den Hora no Miya Palace (secondary capital city): Emperor Junnin
Den Hora no Miya Palace (secondary capital city): Emperor Junnin

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には大社13座10社、小社142座132社の計155座142社が記されている。
sen.e: In 'Jimmyocho' (the list of deities) of 'Engishiki' (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), 13 'za' and 10 'sha' of 'Taisha (grand shrine)' and 142 'za' and 132 'sha' of 'Shosha (small shrine)', namely, 155 'za' and 142 'sha' in total, were recorded.
sen.cmt: 「座」ならびに「社」の定訳が見つけられませんでした。
sen.e: In the Jinmyocho (the list of deities) of Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), 13 'za' and 10 'sha' of Taisha (grand shrine) and 142 'za' and 132 'sha' of Shosha (small shrine), namely, 155 'za' and 142 'sha' in total, were recorded.
sen.cmt: Jimmyocho→Jinmyochoに修正、クォーテーション一部削除
sen.e: In the Jinmyocho (the list of deities) of Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), 13 'za' and 10 'sha' of Taisha (grand shrine) and 142 'za' and 132 'sha' of Shosha (small shrine), namely, 155 'za' and 142 'sha' in total, were recorded.

sen.j: 大社10社は以下に示すもので、全て名神大社である。
sen.e: Taisha' were as follows, and all of them were 'Myojin Taisha' (shrine listed in Engishiki laws).
Taisha were as follows, and all of them were Myojin Taisha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除
sen.e: Taisha were as follows, and all of them were Myojin Taisha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws).

sen.e: Ono-jinja Shrine (Otsu City)

sen.e: Kawata-jinja Shrine

sen.e: Mikami-jinjya shrine

sen.e: Hyozu-jinja Shrine (present-day Hyozu Taisha Shrine)
Hyozu-jinja Shrine (present-day Hyozu-taisha Shrine)
sen.cmt: 表記統一のため、Hyozu-taisha Shrineとしました。

sen.j: 奥津嶋神社 … 現 奥津嶋神社、または現 大嶋神社奥津嶋神社
sen.e: Okutsushima-jinja Shrine (present-day Oshima-Okutsushima-jinja Shrine)
sen.cmt: 「奥津嶋神社 … 現 奥津嶋神社」で、「現」の後の「奥津嶋神社」は省略しています。
sen.e: Okutsushima-jinja Shrine (present-day Okitsushima-jinja Shrine or Oshima-Okutsushima-jinja Shrine)
sen.cmt: 「現 奥津嶋神社、または」を訳出 (参照: http://www.shiga-jinjacho.jp/ycBBS/Board.cgi/02_jinja_db/db/ycDB_02jinja-pc-detail.html?mode:view=1&view:oid=281)
sen.e: Okutsushima-jinja Shrine (present-day Okitsushima-jinja Shrine or Oshima-Okutsushima-jinja Shrine)

sen.j: 伊香具神社
sen.e: Ikagu-jinja Shrine
Ikagu-jinja Shrine
Ikagu-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 水尾神社
sen.e: Mio-jinja shrine
Mio-jinja shrine
Mio-jinja shrine

sen.j: 多賀大社（延喜式では「多何神社」）は小社である。
sen.e: Taga Taisha Shrine (In 'Engishiki,' 'Taga-jinja Shrine' was a 'Shosha.')
sen.cmt: ）は文末に来ると判断しました。
sen.e: Taga-tasha Shrine (In the Engishiki, 'Taga-jinja Shrine' was a Shosha.)
sen.cmt: In 'Engishiki'→In the Engishikiとし、クォーテーション削除、表記統一のためTaga-taisha Shrineとしました。
sen.e: Taga-tasha Shrine (In the Engishiki, 'Taga-jinja Shrine' was a Shosha.)

sen.j: 一宮は建部神社、二宮は日吉大社、三宮は多賀大社あるいは御上神社とされるが、実際には比叡山延暦寺と関係の深い日吉神社の力が強かったと見られている。
sen.e: Although it is considered that 'Ichinomiya,' 'Ninomiya,' and 'Sannomiya' was Takebe-jinja Shrine, Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine, and Taga Taisha Shrine, respectively, it is probable that 'Sannomiya' was Hiyoshi-jinja Shrine, which was deeply related with Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei.

Although it is considered that 'Ichinomiya,' 'Ninomiya,' and 'Sannomiya' were Takebe-jinja Shrine, Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine, and Taga-taisha Shrine or Mikami-jinja Shrine, respectively, it is probable that Hiyoshi-jinja Shrine, which was deeply related with Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei, actually had a strong power.
sen.cmt: 「あるいは御上神社」→訳漏れのため訳出、was→wereに修正、Taga-taisha Shrineとし、原文に沿わない部分を訳し直しました。
sen.e: Although it is considered that 'Ichinomiya,' 'Ninomiya,' and 'Sannomiya' were Takebe-jinja Shrine, Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine, and Taga-taisha Shrine or Mikami-jinja Shrine, respectively, it is probable that Hiyoshi-jinja Shrine, which was deeply related with Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei, actually had a strong power.
